reviews:
The build quality is fantastic: it feels reassuringly solid without being remotely heavy. It has a very comfortable feel for extended single-handed use. The power switch is located at the tail, which is a slightly awkward position but the important control which cycles through the brightness levels is situated along its length, about a third of the way from the tip. Pretty ideal for comfortable thumb operation. Having the two buttons placed adjacent on the side of the torch would have been perfect, but I'm looking too hard for something to complain about.

The light this thing produces is amazing. I was aware of its lumen rating but to see it brighten a pitch black room better than my main lights was surprising. It's far more powerful than torches I own that are twice it's size, weight and require larger batteries.

It's worth noting the overall cost of owning and running this torch will be slightly higher than the individual price of this single item, as it comes without batteries (shocking, I know). It requires a lithium-ion 18650 rechargeable battery, which itself necessitates the purchase of a lithium-ion battery charger. That added about thirty pounds to my purchase, but I have other uses for lithium-ion batteries so it was a worthy investment. It can also be powered by two CR123A batteries but I prefer to use rechargeables.

I can't fault this torch in any way. It outshines my similarly priced, larger, weaker Maglite which I'll now likely give to a sibling. I don't see myself requiring a more powerful torch for my needs, though Fenix have an amazing range and I may feel the need to buy something bigger and brighter..

Amazon's service was exemplary as always, though I wish they'd stop using Parcelforce. I originally intended to buy this torch from a dedicated torch website, but Amazon's price was about fifteen pounds cheaper. That coupled with free one day delivery with my Prime account made perfect sense to buy from here, though Parcelforce seriously screwed up the latter.

review_title: This *IS* the light you're looking for.
reviews:
This is the third from the PD35 line that I've bought over the span of several years. They are simply fantastic.

LIGHT: I like the older model with the button on the side to change brightness and pattern. The light stays on the selected setting through on/off cycles, so if I turn it off in the super bright tactical mode, I know it's going to turn back on into that mode. I carry this for defense and I'm fully confident that when I turn it on to shine in someone's eyes, it's going to be on the bright setting. I've tried several tactical flashlights, including several friends', and this is the brightest I've ever found for a 2xCR123 that's not custom modified. It's even brighter than most of the custom-mod lights I've ever seen.

IMPERFECTIONS: I don't imagine it's US-made; I always prefer things that are but I'm willing to use a superior product that's made overseas if it's the right product. I would also prefer if it had a tactical glass-breaking crown instead of the flat one it comes with. Some of their other models do but they lack other features that are more important to me. I have used it (once) as a defensive weapon, luckily only briefly and without consequence. If it hadn't been flat, I may have used it as a striking weapon that time. There is nothing critical about this product that is wrong in my opinion.

SERVICE: Everything I carry wears constantly and breaks eventually. This broke when I dropped it on a hard surface one day, just a random thing. I've dropped them, submersed them, thrown them, etc., probably dozens of times, and once, one just broke. It was out of warranty. I contacted Fenix (all email) and they put me in touch with their US service partner, Land Run. I got an RMA and sent in the light. Despite being out of warranty, they fixed it for free on their own initiative and sent it back. It was fixed and cleaned -- the lens was brand new -- with free batteries. The whole process took a couple months but I couldn't be happier with their service. They truly stand behind their product.

VALUE: It's inexpensive, generally indestructible and extremely bright. I have friends who use this same model with rechargeable batteries, with success. On the brightest mode, it's bright enough to temporarily blind someone; in sunlight, the blinding effect won't last long but it's still there. I've tried it. On the dimmest mode, for utility use, it's just bright enough to illuminate something a few feet away on a sunny Texas day. I've used very expensive alternatives (Streamlight) that aren't as bright for a significantly higher unit cost. The batteries seem to last practically forever: of 3 lights I've had for a combined over 10 years of service, using them mostly for utility use and occasionally on bright, I've had to change batteries twice. Lithium batteries have a practically infinite shelf life and I'm highly confident carrying one of these as a defensive tool or mounted on a go rifle (there are excellent mounting accessories, which I also have), knowing that it's definitely going to come through for me when I need it. All this comes for what seems to be a third the cost of the other reliable options.

If this light meets your selection criteria, I would recommend it as the clear first -- maybe only -- choice.

reviews:
I paired the PD35 with the Fenix quick-release bike-mount. I already owned a couple comparable EDC 4Sevens, that I love, but I needed a light with a dedicated switch to change output levels. If you mount it with the grey button up, it's very easy to change while riding. You're given a variety of output levels, with medium having a good balance between battery life and output. High is bright! When I received the PD35 and bike mount, the next day I rode through the 2.3 mile train tunnel on the Iron Horse Trail outside Seattle. That's as dark as it gets. The high setting felt like a car's headlights.

I was considering the TK22, but found it had more throw (not always preferred!), but less flood than the PD35. So for my use, this light is just-right for a bicycle. You'll have enough throw to see what's coming down a dark mountain trail and wide enough to be aware of your surroundings without any rings or bright spots (TK22) obscuring terrain.

If you're looking for a reliable "bikepacking" light, this is it.
